qas.question: Who started the Bow Street detectives?
How did the Bow Street group pay their employees?
How did the Thames River Police pay their employees?

answers.text: full-time, salaried officers prohibited from taking private fees

qas.question: Who came up with the concept of the 'new' police?
What schedule did the Thames River Police employees work?
Who fired the Bow Street detectives?
How did the Bow Street group get paid by their employees?

plausible_answers.text: full-time, salaried officers prohibited from taking private fees

qas.question: How did the James River Police pay their employees?
Who rejected the concept of the 'new' police?
What schedule did the Thames River Police employees not work?

context: Colquhoun's utilitarian approach to the problem – using a cost-benefit argument to obtain support from businesses standing to benefit – allowed him to achieve what <a0_0><b5_0>Henry and John Fielding<b5_0/><a0_0/> failed for their Bow Street detectives. Unlike the <a1_0><b6_0>stipendiary system<b6_0/><a1_0/> at Bow Street, the river police were <a2_0><a4_0><b7_0><b9_0>full-time<b9_0/><a4_0/>, salaried officers prohibited from taking private fees<b7_0/><a2_0/>. His other contribution was the concept of preventive policing; his police were to act as a highly visible deterrent to crime by their permanent presence on the Thames. Colquhoun's innovations were a critical development leading up to <a3_0><b8_0>Robert Peel<b8_0/><a3_0/>'s "new" police three decades later.
